STRU-BENPM v.2
				
				Bachelor of Engineering Pre-Major
Subject or unit name 3: STEN2005 (v.1) Structural Analysis of Determinate Structures
Subject or unit name 6: STEN2006 (v.1) Structural Analysis of Indeterminate Structures
Subject or unit name 7: CVEN2000 (v.1) Civil Engineering Drawing and Surveying
Subject or unit name 10: WSEN2000 (v.1) Water Quality and Resources Engineering
subject or unit description 2: Introduction (basic properties of fluids), flow fields (steady/unsteady flow, streamlines), velocity profile (Couette flow) and Newton's law of viscosity, Reynolds number. Hydrostatics, control-volume analysis - mass conservation and momentum equation and applications of CV analysis. Bernoulli equation, measurement of pressure, flow speed and volumetric flow rate, and applications of Bernoulli equation (Froude propeller theory). One-dimensional energy equation, laminar flow in pipes and channels, laminar-to-turbulent transition, turbulent flow in pipes, index and logarithmic laws, wall-roughness, Moody chart, hydraulic grade lines, boundary layers (laminar and turbulent), drag, dimensional analysis, dynamic similarity, pump types and characterisation.
subject or unit description 3: This unit introduces classical methods of analysis to enable students to assess, quantify and communicate an understanding of Statically Determinate Structures’ behaviours. The syllabus includes types of structures and loads, analysis of statically determinate structures (including beams, frames and trusses), deflection elastic beam theory, deflections using and geometrical and energy methods, and influence lines for statically determinate structures.
subject or unit description 4: Strength, behaviour and durability properties, production and protection of commonly utilised Civil Engineering materials (Concrete, Steel, Timber, Asphalt and Geotextiles) are examined, along with methods of calculating stresses and strains in materials under different loading conditions. Geometric properties (Area, Centroid, I, Z, S) are determined in order to calculate normal and shear stresses due to applied Axial, Bending, Shear and Torsion actions. Material properties (E, G, Poisson’s Ratio) are examined and utilised in order to determine normal and shear strains due to normal and shear stresses. The basic relationships between normal stress and strain are expanded upon with the investigation into general beam equations, general strain equations, compatibility, composite beam behaviour and plastic behaviour of beams. Shear stresses and strains due to shear forces and torsion in circular shafts are introduced. Biaxial Stress systems, and the combination of normal and shear stresses, are analysed using Mohr’s circles of stress and strain, and stress transformation equations. Combined stresses due to combined loadings complete the stress and strain analysis component of the unit.
subject or unit description 5: The unit is on the analysis of stresses in structural elements for different types of actions. It contains stresses for flexure, shear and torsional actions in solid and thin walled sections, stresses for unsymmetrical bending, combinations and transformation of stresses, stress and strain tensors and failure analysis.
subject or unit description 6: This unit introduces classical methods of analysis to enable students to assess, quantify and communicate an understanding of Statically Indeterminate Structures’ behaviours. The syllabus includes analysis of statically indeterminate structures by the force method, displacement method, slope deflection method and moment distribution method, influence lines for statically indeterminate structures and application of key concepts of compatibility, flexibility and stiffness.
subject or unit description 8: Sustainable development is about forms of progress that combine economic development, social advancement, environmental protection and is widely recognised by the public, private and civic sectors as one of the key challenges for the 21st century. Deals with the contribution of engineering to the development and implementation of sustainable solutions.  Introduction to the sustainable development agenda. Practical methods and tools for development and implementation of sustainable solutions which complement generic 'good engineering and management practice'. Introduction to sustainable technology development.
subject or unit description 9: This unit introduces students to geotechnical engineering. Students will learn about engineering geology and the physical properties and classification of soils as a geotechnical engineering material. Students will also develop an understanding of the fundamental concepts of stresses, seepage and compaction in soil masses.
subject or unit description 10: This unit introduces the concepts and methods of analysing water quality, including chemical, biological and physical quality measures. It will introduce water resources, comprising identification and analysis of common types of water sources. Students will evaluate typical qualities, variabilities, applications, and indicative treatment methods of water. The legislation of water quality, including drinking water guidelines will be analysed as to its principles and purpose. Identification and basic analysis of the principles and methods of conventional water and wastewater treatment recycling and re-use will be addressed.

Career outcomes: Metallurgist, Plant metallurgist, Process metallurgist, Processing consultant
Remarks: Curtin requires all applicants to demonstrate proficiency in English. Specific English requirements for this course are outlined in the IELTS table below.
Subject or unit name 2: NPSC1003 (v.2) Integrating Indigenous Science and STEM
Subject or unit name 6: CHEM1000 (v.1) Principles and Processes in Chemistry
subject or unit description 1: This unit aims at equipping students with the ability to write simple programs as part of managing large volumes of data. Topics include data representation in a computer, algorithm design, submodules, Boolean expressions, selection and repetition control structures, basic Object Oriented programming design and File I/O. These will be discussed in the context of implementation in the Python programming language.
subject or unit description 2: Students will be introduced to Indigenous science, history, culture, knowledge and practices, and the value of integrating different knowledge systems to address global challenges. This unit focuses on developing the capacity of students to research, evaluate and communicate scientific and cultural information and arguments using written, visual and oral presentation techniques, while demonstrating inter-cultural awareness, scientific standards and academic integrity. In tandem, related ethical issues within STEM are explored, and particularly, the historic use of scientific ideas to justify social and political actions. The nature of science and scientific behaviours, the role and relevance of science and other knowledge systems in society, and methods of scientific inquiry are introduced to foster students' professional identities as scientists in Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) fields in the 21st century.
subject or unit description 3: This unit introduces and establishes the ideas of calculus and how the techniques of calculus can be used in solving problems in science, engineering and business-related fields. Students will learn the necessary skills to solve such problems through the application and techniques of both differential and integral calculus. This unit will cover a variety of techniques of differentiation and integration, and by using these methods of calculus students will learn to solve several types of problems such as optimisation, areas and volumes. This unit will also build upon the students’ knowledge of trigonometry, extending into the areas of identities, solving trigonometric equations as well as applying calculus to the trigonometric functions.
subject or unit description 4: This unit builds on students’ knowledge of calculus, further extending to a range of techniques used in solving problems arising from science, engineering and business related fields. Students will extend their differentiation skills to implicit, logarithmic and partial differentiation, and will apply their differentiation techniques to optimisation problems and the approximation of functions. This unit will cover a range of integration techniques, and students will apply these to find volume, length and surface area. Students will also learn to solve a variety of first and second order differential equations, and be introduced to several techniques for testing the convergence of a series. This unit is designed for those students who have passed Mathematics Methods ATAR or equivalent.
subject or unit description 5: This unit will consider problems arising from science, engineering and business related fields. Students will learn the necessary skills to model and solve such problems through the introduction of mathematical techniques of linear algebra as well as complex analysis. Students will be introduced to idea of a complex number together with their applications and use in solutions to polynomial equations. This unit will cover vectors, lines and planes and their extension into n-dimension space. This unit also covers matrices and their use for solving systems of linear equations through a study of a number of different types of solution methods. Eigenvalues and eigenvectors will be considered. This unit is designed for those students who have passed WACE Mathematical Applications or Mathematical Methods or equivalent.
subject or unit description 6: This unit is designed for students who have passed WACE Chemistry 3A/3B or equivalent. Students who have not previously studied chemistry should take CHEM1003 Introduction to Chemistry. An exploration of the historical pattern of thought will illustrate that chemistry is both testable and contestable and that theories may be limited by or to certain conditions. Physical and chemical properties of molecules, such as polarity, intermolecular forces, colour and magnetism, will illustrate how a fundamental understanding of atomic theory can explain macroscopic observations. Energy is the interconvertible capacity to do work, however not all energy can be converted into work and is usually transferred in the form of heat. Heat transfer can be measured in some reactions to predict the heat transfer in other reactions. Electrochemical processes can be utilised to provide energy in the form of electricity without many of the limitations of other energy production systems. Applications of electrochemical energy conversion will be investigated. The purpose and limitations of chemical measurement will be explored by highlighting its role in everyday life and the breadth of techniques, methodologies and instruments available to perform analyses of relevant species.
subject or unit description 7: This is a first year level non calculus unit for students who have not previously studied Physics. Students who have passed Physics ATAR and Mathematics Methods ATAR or equivalent should instead take PHYS1005 Physics 1. Foundations of Physics provides an introduction to some of the fundamental principles of classical mechanics, kinematics and dynamics, circular motion, gravitation, mechanical energy, thermal properties of matter, gas laws, simple harmonic motion, wave motion and sound, electrical charges, static and current electricity, DC Circuits, electromagnetism, electrical safety, optics, microscope, human vision, atomic and nuclear radiation physics. Students will examine the fundamentals of experimental methods, including accuracy and precision, interpretation of physical measurements, graphical representation of data and uncertainties of measurement.
subject or unit description 8: This unit is an introduction to the fundamental nature of matter for students who have not previously studied chemistry. Students who have passed WACE Chemistry 3A/3B or equivalent should instead take CHEM1000 Principles and Processes in Chemistry or CHEM1001 Biological Chemistry. A range of chemical processes that underpin a broad array of disciplines will illustrate the importance of and differences between chemical and mathematical representations of reactions and reactivity. The physical phenomena resulting from bond types and their resulting intermolecular forces will explain the properties of natural and man-made processes and materials. Using examples from nature and biology the role of the certain groups in ascribing reactivity and function of organic molecules will be highlighted.
subject or unit description 9: Through the activities of lectures, tutorials and practical laboratories, you will study introductory Statics, Dynamics and Fluid Mechanics. Statics considers bodies in equilibrium and this requires the application of Newton's Laws along with the understanding and manipulation of vector quantities: forces, equilibrium and couples. Free-body diagrams are applied to the analysis of simple trusses and internal actions within beams. Internal axial stress and strain are studied in relation to Hooke’s Law and material properties. The principle of compatibility is applied to statically indeterminate problems. The properties of area required for beam bending analysis are covered. Dynamics is addressed via kinematics and kinetics of particles and rigid bodies but limited to two-dimensions. Rectilinear, curvilinear and relative motion are described in x-y and n-t coordinates. Newton's second law is applied directly and also via work-energy principles and impulse-momentum principles. Kinetics of rigid bodies and rotation about a fixed axis are studied. Fluid mechanics commences with fluid statics, hydrostatic pressure and fluid forces on simple structures. Fluid dynamics is studied via Bernoulli’s equation and momentum flux. This unit is designed for those students who have passed WACE Mathematics Methods or equivalent.
subject or unit description 10: Electricity is the greatest energy source of our time. Engineers from all disciplines need to have a basic understanding of the fundamental principles of this valuable energy source, as well as the main tools and techniques used to specify and analyse electrical circuits. This unit covers the fundamentals of Direct Current (DC) and Alternating Current (AC) circuit analysis. The use of electricity in electro-mechanical and electronic systems is covered, with emphasis in instrumentation and control. To complete the picture, computer embedded systems are introduced as a tool for monitoring and controlling engineering processes, whether they be a bridge, a refinery, or a robot. On completion of this unit, students should be able to participate in a multidisciplinary conversation about electrical systems.

Faculty: WASM: Minerals, Energy and Chemical Engineering (WASM-MECE)
Prerequiste_1:
Writing
6.0, Speaking
6.0, Reading
6.0, Listening
6.0, Overall band score
6.0
Description: Chemical or ‘process’ engineering involves finding the best sequence of chemical and physical processing operations, plus the right operating conditions, to convert raw materials into higher-value products.
Career outcomes: Chemical engineer, Process engineer, Production/operations engineer, Risk and safety manager
Remarks: Curtin requires all applicants to demonstrate proficiency in English. Specific English requirements for this course are outlined in the IELTS table below.
Subject or unit name 1:
STRU-OLGAS v.1
				
				Oil and Gas Stream (BEng Hons)
Subject or unit name 2:
STRU-CHEMG v.1
				
				Chemical Engineering Stream (BEng Hons)
Subject or unit name 4: CHEM1000 (v.1) Principles and Processes in Chemistry
Subject or unit name 8: CHEM1002 (v.1) Reactivity and Function in Chemistry
subject or unit description 3: Modes of heat transfer, energy balances; Conduction (1-D & 2-D steady, lumped & 1-D transient); Heat exchangers (types, OHTC, fouling, LMTD and e-NTU analyses, detailed design of shell and tube heat exchangers); Convection ( forced convection correlations for internal & external flow, free convection correlations, boiling and condensation equations); Radiation (the blackbody, radiative surface properties, Kirchhoff’s law, view factors, radiation network diagrams, radiation exchange between surfaces, radiation shields)
subject or unit description 4: This unit is designed for students who have passed WACE Chemistry 3A/3B or equivalent. Students who have not previously studied chemistry should take CHEM1003 Introduction to Chemistry. An exploration of the historical pattern of thought will illustrate that chemistry is both testable and contestable and that theories may be limited by or to certain conditions. Physical and chemical properties of molecules, such as polarity, intermolecular forces, colour and magnetism, will illustrate how a fundamental understanding of atomic theory can explain macroscopic observations. Energy is the interconvertible capacity to do work, however not all energy can be converted into work and is usually transferred in the form of heat. Heat transfer can be measured in some reactions to predict the heat transfer in other reactions. Electrochemical processes can be utilised to provide energy in the form of electricity without many of the limitations of other energy production systems. Applications of electrochemical energy conversion will be investigated. The purpose and limitations of chemical measurement will be explored by highlighting its role in everyday life and the breadth of techniques, methodologies and instruments available to perform analyses of relevant species.
subject or unit description 5: This unit introduces students to one of the most fundamental, useful and important tools that chemical and process engineers use: material and energy balances. They help us understand, analyse, design, troubleshoot and optimise industrial processes that involve physical changes and chemical transformations. Students are taken through the following topics: Introductory Concepts (dimensions, systems of units, basis of calculations, moles and concentrations); Material Balances without Reaction; Flow Diagrams; Material Balances involving Reactions; Material Balance for Combustion Systems; Multi-unit Systems (including recycle, bypass and purge); Industrial Applications; Material Balances involving Ideal Gases; Multiphase Equilibrium; Energy Balances (terminology and types of energy); Energy Balances without Reaction; Energy Balances accounting for Chemical Reaction (heat of formation, heat of reaction, sensible and latent heats, heat of combustion); Combined Material and Energy Balances. The unit provides an insight into the way chemical engineers approach problems and supplies concepts that underlie many other study units in the curriculum.
subject or unit description 6: Introduction (basic properties of fluids), flow fields (steady/unsteady flow, streamlines), velocity profile (Couette flow) and Newton's law of viscosity, Reynolds number. Hydrostatics, control-volume analysis - mass conservation and momentum equation and applications of CV analysis. Bernoulli equation, measurement of pressure, flow speed and volumetric flow rate, and applications of Bernoulli equation (Froude propeller theory). One-dimensional energy equation, laminar flow in pipes and channels, laminar-to-turbulent transition, turbulent flow in pipes, index and logarithmic laws, wall-roughness, Moody chart, hydraulic grade lines, boundary layers (laminar and turbulent), drag, dimensional analysis, dynamic similarity, pump types and characterisation.
subject or unit description 7: The objective of this unit is to learn the basic concepts of thermodynamics and apply them to relevant chemical engineering situations. Initially, students will learn to differentiate between various forms of energy and understand their relationship to each other. This will be followed by the derivation of mathematical relations for various thermodynamic properties. Then students will learn key equations of state and their use in predicting thermodynamic properties. An introduction to the laws of thermodynamics will be provided. Finally the students will be introduced to vapour-liquid equilibria and chemical equilibria and will learn how to perform equilibrium calculations to predict the results of chemical reactions.
subject or unit description 8: This unit is designed for students who have passed CHEM1000 Principles and Processes in Chemistry or CHEM1001 Biological Chemistry. This unit will prepare you for a wide array of future careers by illustrating how an understanding of reactivity and function assists understanding biological, medicinal, geological and industrial processes. It will provide you with the skills to predict reactions of common functional groups by demonstrating how the mechanistic process gives the outcomes of new, but related reactions, including reactions of relevance to your chosen discipline. Chemical reactions occur over a very wide range of timescales and the ability to measure and predict the rates of reaction, particularly as they are influenced by a number of factors, will display how this has direct influence on your everyday life. Finally, dynamic systems in biology, medicine, industry and nature will illustrate the importance of chemical equilibria.
subject or unit description 9: In Process Mass Transfer, students will learn the fundamental theory and introductory practical applications of separation processes. The fundamental theory they will study includes molecular diffusion, convective mass transfer, interphase mass transfer, the two-film model, film and overall mass transfer coefficients and vapour-liquid equilibrium. Mass transfer theory is used to design and analyse unit operations for separation processes. These include flash and continuous distillation, gas absorption and stripping, solvent extraction, solid leaching and humidification. The methods used to study the unit operations are material balances for stage and continuous contact processes, McCabe-Thiele design methods, and packed tower design.
subject or unit description 10: This unit covers methods used for the numerical solution and analysis of process flowsheets. After an introduction to process engineering software and revision of flowsheet concepts, the topics discussed include the numerical solution of algebraic and ordinary differential equations; spreadsheet functions for data analysis and optimisation; flowsheet tear analysis; and introductory process simulation using Excel/VBA (Visual Basic for Applications). Process flowsheets are also solved using a commercial process simulator, such as Aspen Hysys or UniSim Design. Students cover the selection of species, thermodynamic property package and unit models; techniques for successful process simulation; conducting sensitivity studies and optimisation; and dealing with uncertain information. The unit emphasises the need to set out simulations clearly, justify the approach taken and evaluate the computed results. Students develop teamwork and communication skills in the context of solving and analysing process flowsheets.

Faculty: School of Electrical Engineering, Computing and Mathematical Sciences (EECMS)
Prerequiste_1:
Writing
6.0, Speaking
6.0, Reading
6.0, Listening
6.0, Overall band score
6.5
Description: Rapid advances in electronic communication, the ‘internet of things’, and renewable and sustainable energy offer abundant career opportunities in electrical and electronic engineering.
Career outcomes: Electrical engineer, Electrical power engineer, Electronics engineer, Communications engineer, Embedded systems engineer, Medical systems engineer, Network controller, Power systems engineer, Systems engineer
Remarks: Curtin requires all applicants to demonstrate proficiency in English. Specific English requirements for this course are outlined in the IELTS table below.
Subject or unit name 6: ELEN2001 (v.1) Electromagnetic and Electromechanical Energy Conversion
Subject or unit name 9: ELEN3002 (v.3) Fundamentals of Engineering Electromagnetics and Transmission Lines
subject or unit description 1: Review of Direct Current (DC) resistive circuits and circuit theorems.  Nodal Voltage and Mesh Current methods of analysis.  Introduction to Alternate Current (AC) circuits and coupling circuits (mutual inductance and transformers).  Balanced and unbalanced 3-phase circuits and power calculations.  Frequency responses of Resistive-Inductive-Capacitive (R-L-C) circuits.  Transient circuit analysis, First and second orders.  Use of Laplace Transform in Circuit Analysis.  Operational amplifiers and Active filter circuits.
subject or unit description 2: This unit introduces students to the C programming language and the related concepts and tools used to design, implement, test and debug C programs. Topics covered include: C Fundamentals. Functions and program structure. Designing programs with derived types. Pointers. Abstract data types. Strings, streams and input/output (I/O). Dynamic memory allocation and C programming utilitiers for program construction and diagnosis.
subject or unit description 3: This unit focuses on digital design and computer architecture. It provides grounding on the foundations of digital logic design from the perspective of a Microprocessor without Interlocked Pipeline Storage (MIPS) processor architecture. Basic techniques on Boolean algebra and minimisation are covered to design combinational circuits and sequential systems which are building blocks to a MIPS. Using Electronic Design Automation (EDA) tools and Very High Speed Integrated Circuit Hardware Description Language (VHDL) and examining assembly programs, students will be able to gain further understanding in the complex world of computer architecture design.
subject or unit description 4: Sequences and series leading to Taylor’s series; Multidimensional analysis 2-D to n-D functions. Curve, plane and volume parameterisation. Complex functions. Graphing functions;  2-D, 3-D, n-D calculus. Line integrals. Surface integrals. Volume integrals. Iterated integrals; Probability theory. Sample space, events and the definition of probability. Joint and conditional probabilities, Bayes’ theorem, independent events and Bernoulli trials. Discrete and continues random variables, cumulative distribution functions, probability mass functions, probability density functions. Expectations, variances, functions of random variables. Engineering applications and probability theory.
subject or unit description 5: The course will cover continuous-time and discrete-time signals, specifically their mathematical representations, properties and classifications, such as power and energy signals.  Special attention is devoted to Linear time-invariant systems, where concepts such as impulse response, convolution are developed. The course also cover the Fourier series representation of periodic signals, which leads to continuous-time Fourier transform (and discrete-time Fourier transform), Laplace transform and Sampling theorem. Students will be introduced to Matlab.
subject or unit description 6: Review of 3 Phase Circuits & Singly and Doubly Excited Systems. Review of magnetic circuit theory and flux linkages.   Three Phase Induction Motors.Transformers. Direct Current (DC) Motors.Single Phase Induction Motors. Fractional Horsepower motors.
subject or unit description 7: Topics to be addressed in this unit will include semiconductor doping, PN junction, diodes and circuits, physics of bipolar junction transistor, introduction on field effect transistor, elementary transistor amplification circuits, transistor biasing, device modelling, analysis and design of linear (small signal) single-stage amplifiers.
subject or unit description 8: The von Neumann architecture. Instruction sets and memory maps. Some common microcomputer families. Organisation of simple processor, memory and input/output (I/O) systems. Assembly level programming, programming techniques. Development Environments Introduction to event-driven structures. Interfacing concepts. Some peripheral and system busses. Implementation methods for microcomputers. Introduction to High level programming for embedded systems using C language.
subject or unit description 9: Electromagnetism is an aspect of electrical engineering in which we apply physical reasoning and mathematics to describe fundamental quantities and components such as voltage, current, resistors, capacitors and inductors. While circuit theory allows us to calculate the overall result, electromagnetism explains why the components behave the way they do. You will learn that capacitors store electric fields and inductors store magnetic fields, and that time variation of field quantities causes electric and magnetic fields to ‘couple’. This knowledge will be applied to describe information and power transfer through transmission lines. This phenomenon is also responsible for electromagnetic radiation which permits wireless transmission of information.
subject or unit description 10: Overview and history of feedback control. Mathematical modelling of physical systems including thermal, fluid, electromechanical and mechanical.  Interpretation of the dynamic response of low order systems in both the time, frequency and s domain.  Feedback and stability.  Stability assessment techniques, root locus analysis.  Response specifications, time and (mention of) frequency.  Introduction to controllers.  PID algorithms and tuning. Sampled data systems and digital control systems.

Faculty: WASM: Minerals, Energy and Chemical Engineering (WASM-MECE)
Description: Petroleum engineers extract oil and gas from deposits below the Earth’s surface. They collaborate with other professionals to understand the geological and geophysical characteristics of particular reservoirs, before designing, testing and implementing the most effective and profitable extraction method.
Career outcomes: Petroleum engineer, Drilling engineer, Field operation engineer, Production engineer, Reservoir engineer, Subsurface engineer, Well completions engineer
Remarks: At Curtin, we understand that everyone’s study journey has been different.
Subject or unit name 5: MCEN2000 (v.1) Fundamentals of Strength of Materials
Subject or unit name 8: CHEM1000 (v.1) Principles and Processes in Chemistry
Subject or unit name 9: PEEN2000 (v.1) Petrophysics and Reservoir Properties Laboratory
subject or unit description 1: Sustainable development is about forms of progress that combine economic development, social advancement, environmental protection and is widely recognised by the public, private and civic sectors as one of the key challenges for the 21st century. Deals with the contribution of engineering to the development and implementation of sustainable solutions.  Introduction to the sustainable development agenda. Practical methods and tools for development and implementation of sustainable solutions which complement generic 'good engineering and management practice'. Introduction to sustainable technology development.
subject or unit description 2: Introduction (basic properties of fluids), flow fields (steady/unsteady flow, streamlines), velocity profile (Couette flow) and Newton's law of viscosity, Reynolds number. Hydrostatics, control-volume analysis - mass conservation and momentum equation and applications of CV analysis. Bernoulli equation, measurement of pressure, flow speed and volumetric flow rate, and applications of Bernoulli equation (Froude propeller theory). One-dimensional energy equation, laminar flow in pipes and channels, laminar-to-turbulent transition, turbulent flow in pipes, index and logarithmic laws, wall-roughness, Moody chart, hydraulic grade lines, boundary layers (laminar and turbulent), drag, dimensional analysis, dynamic similarity, pump types and characterisation.
subject or unit description 3: An introduction to planet Earth and its geological resources. Students will examine key rock types (igneous, sedimentary and metamorphic) and how their constituent minerals and structures define a range of rock properties. They will also infer 3-dimensional patterns of rock units and structures from maps, cross-sections and stereographic projections; and, identify key ore and fossil fuel deposit types and learn how their size, shape and location are controlled by the spatial arrangement of rock types and structures. Fieldwork will form part of the learning experiences where students will apply their theoretical knowledge to understand the geology of a particular area.
subject or unit description 4: Role of the petroleum engineer and other associated professionals in petroleum exploration and production industries; the nature of oil and gas; the formation of oil and gas; source rock, reservoir rock, and petroleum traps; overview of petroleum exploration and production process; an introduction to drilling and production engineering; basic rock and fluid properties, and Darcy’s Law.
subject or unit description 5: Introduction for Strength of Materials. Normal stresses and strains. Shear stresses and strains. Hooke’s law in tension and shear, Poisson’s ratio. The concepts of allowable stresses, factor of safety. Computation of changes in length of axially loaded members, uniform and nonuniform bars. Statically indeterminate structures. Formulation of the torsion formula and its applications. Stresses and strains in pure shear. Types of beams and different boundary conditions. Construction of shear force and bending diagrams. Formulation and applications of flexure formula based on the Euler beam theory. Design of beams for bending stresses. Formulation of the shear formula. Design of beams for shear stresses. Centroids and second moments of plane sections. Parallel axis theorem. Analysis of stresses and strains for plane stress problems. Mohr’s circle for plane problems. Thin-walled pressure vessels. Combined loadings. Deflections of beams, the integration methods.
subject or unit description 6: This unit introduces students to one of the most fundamental, useful and important tools that chemical and process engineers use: material and energy balances. They help us understand, analyse, design, troubleshoot and optimise industrial processes that involve physical changes and chemical transformations. Students are taken through the following topics: Introductory Concepts (dimensions, systems of units, basis of calculations, moles and concentrations); Material Balances without Reaction; Flow Diagrams; Material Balances involving Reactions; Material Balance for Combustion Systems; Multi-unit Systems (including recycle, bypass and purge); Industrial Applications; Material Balances involving Ideal Gases; Multiphase Equilibrium; Energy Balances (terminology and types of energy); Energy Balances without Reaction; Energy Balances accounting for Chemical Reaction (heat of formation, heat of reaction, sensible and latent heats, heat of combustion); Combined Material and Energy Balances. The unit provides an insight into the way chemical engineers approach problems and supplies concepts that underlie many other study units in the curriculum.
subject or unit description 7: The objective of this unit is to learn the basic concepts of thermodynamics and apply them to relevant chemical engineering situations. Initially, students will learn to differentiate between various forms of energy and understand their relationship to each other. This will be followed by the derivation of mathematical relations for various thermodynamic properties. Then students will learn key equations of state and their use in predicting thermodynamic properties. An introduction to the laws of thermodynamics will be provided. Finally the students will be introduced to vapour-liquid equilibria and chemical equilibria and will learn how to perform equilibrium calculations to predict the results of chemical reactions.
subject or unit description 8: This unit is designed for students who have passed WACE Chemistry 3A/3B or equivalent. Students who have not previously studied chemistry should take CHEM1003 Introduction to Chemistry. An exploration of the historical pattern of thought will illustrate that chemistry is both testable and contestable and that theories may be limited by or to certain conditions. Physical and chemical properties of molecules, such as polarity, intermolecular forces, colour and magnetism, will illustrate how a fundamental understanding of atomic theory can explain macroscopic observations. Energy is the interconvertible capacity to do work, however not all energy can be converted into work and is usually transferred in the form of heat. Heat transfer can be measured in some reactions to predict the heat transfer in other reactions. Electrochemical processes can be utilised to provide energy in the form of electricity without many of the limitations of other energy production systems. Applications of electrochemical energy conversion will be investigated. The purpose and limitations of chemical measurement will be explored by highlighting its role in everyday life and the breadth of techniques, methodologies and instruments available to perform analyses of relevant species.
subject or unit description 9: The objectives of Petrophysics units are for students to become familiar with reservoir rocks petrophysical characteristics and their methods of measurements. This unit is composed of: an introduction to rocks and pore filling fluids; coring methods; and core handling and preservation procedures; routine and special core analysis methods; porosity, permeability; relative permeability, electrical and acoustic properties of rock measurements; hydrocarbon reservoir fluid properties measurements.
subject or unit description 10: Borehole environment and logging procedure, Log data QC, Log editing and calliper logs, Spontaneous potential (SP) logs, principles and applications, Gamma ray and spectral gamma ray, Principles of sonic logging and applications, Density logging and litho-density, principles and applications, Neutron logging, principles and quantitative interpretation, Applications of combined density and neutron logging data, Resistivity logging and measurement principles, Electrical properties of reservoir rocks and Archie's relationships, Log interpretation procedure in clean formations, Log interpretation in shaly formations.

Faculty: WASM: Minerals, Energy and Chemical Engineering (WASM-MECE)
Description: Mining engineering is where the latest technology is used to extract minerals from the earth safely and efficiently.
Career outcomes: Mining engineer, Management consultant, Mine manager, Mine planner and designer, Mining company director, Operations manager
Remarks: Please select a country above.
Subject or unit name 6: MINE2006 (v.1) Introduction to Mining and Digital Applications
subject or unit description 1: Introduction (basic properties of fluids), flow fields (steady/unsteady flow, streamlines), velocity profile (Couette flow) and Newton's law of viscosity, Reynolds number. Hydrostatics, control-volume analysis - mass conservation and momentum equation and applications of CV analysis. Bernoulli equation, measurement of pressure, flow speed and volumetric flow rate, and applications of Bernoulli equation (Froude propeller theory). One-dimensional energy equation, laminar flow in pipes and channels, laminar-to-turbulent transition, turbulent flow in pipes, index and logarithmic laws, wall-roughness, Moody chart, hydraulic grade lines, boundary layers (laminar and turbulent), drag, dimensional analysis, dynamic similarity, pump types and characterisation.
subject or unit description 2: An introduction to planet Earth and its geological resources. Students will examine key rock types (igneous, sedimentary and metamorphic) and how their constituent minerals and structures define a range of rock properties. They will also infer 3-dimensional patterns of rock units and structures from maps, cross-sections and stereographic projections; and, identify key ore and fossil fuel deposit types and learn how their size, shape and location are controlled by the spatial arrangement of rock types and structures. Fieldwork will form part of the learning experiences where students will apply their theoretical knowledge to understand the geology of a particular area.
subject or unit description 3: This unit will provide a broad introduction to four key aspects of data science: data retrieval and manipulation, data visualisation, statistical computation and machine learning, and presentation and communication. Students will use data from a variety of sources, be introduced to contemporary computing and database environments such as R and SQL, and be exposed to case studies from outside the classroom. Through this unit students will become acquainted with the challenges of contemporary data science and gain an appreciation of the foundational skills necessary to turn data into information.
subject or unit description 4: In this unit students will be introduced to the fundamentals of mining economics, including project evaluation and economic decision- making techniques used in the mining industry. Students will study mineral and energy markets and the concept of supply and demand. They will also learn about approaches to quantifying economic risk components associated with mining, such as financial and technical uncertainty and environmental and social risks. Students will develop their knowledge and skills in estimating the full cost of capital and operating expenditure associated with developing, operating and closing a mine. They will learn how to use discounted cash flow and real option analysis methods as tools to adapt and revise economic valuations of mining projects under uncertain and fluctuating conditions.
subject or unit description 5: An introduction to the main technologies and techniques currently used for mineral processing in the mining industry. Students will gain a conceptual understanding of mineral processing by applying various terms and principles to extractive metallurgical processes, and will learn about the key role that mineral processing plays in the mining value chain and how mining practices can impact on processing outcomes. They will be introduced to three overarching processes: the comminution and liberation of minerals; the separation of minerals; and, the extraction of metals, including emerging approaches, technologies and digital applications in these areas. The unit will enable students to specify appropriate methods for processing a variety of ore types, as well as the relevant underlying phenomena involved. Sustainability issues will be examined, ranging from energy consumption to environment considerations, and safety risks associated with mining processing operations, as well as factors impacting efficiency and cost of the processing system. Students will also have the opportunity to develop their academic and professional communication skills through exposure to, and application of, terms and principles relevant to extractive metallurgical processes.
subject or unit description 6: In this unit students will be introduced to the concepts of ‘value chain’ and ‘life of mine’ and will learn about main mining methods currently used in the industry and how they evolved over time. They will also gain an understanding of how new approaches to the collection and use of data are transforming mining across the value chain. Students will be introduced to the use of advanced sensor data analytics to inform decision-making in the mining context. There will also be opportunities to learn about state-of-the-art developments in digital mining systems through field visits and engagement with industry experts.
subject or unit description 7: This unit introduces the applications of surveying and geographic information systems (GIS) methods to mining. Students will be introduced to data collection methods for open cut and underground mines (levelling, traversing and GPS and their associated instruments). Once collected by students the data will, be processed in a GIS for manipulating and mapping. This will entail: utilising GIS software for data processing; input and representation of data (quality and management); storage and manipulation of geospatial data; cartographic and map design; interpretation of the resulting mine maps. The unit will examine the role of the mine surveyor in supporting machine guidance of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), data integrity associated with the mine site and mapping on a mine site. Students will also develop their collaborative and communication skills through fieldwork activities.
subject or unit description 8: This unit provides students with a comprehensive and practical understanding of the range of impacts that mining may have on society and the environment. Broadly, the unit covers the concept of mining and sustainability; responses of government, industry and private firms to the sustainability agenda; environmental management in mining (including water, waste, acid and metalliferous drainage, and mine closure planning); social and cultural issues in mining, and best practice for environmental and social impacts of mining. Students will acquire an understanding of state-of-the-art techniques in environmental management of mine sites as well as being able to identify the major issues and management strategies associated with social/community engagement and impacts, particularly in relation to Indigenous communities in Australia and internationally. Students’ communication and collaborative skills will also be developed in this unit. Students will also be required to participate in fieldwork activities and industry based problem solving.
subject or unit description 9: As an introduction to the fundamental engineering science and analytical principles of soil and rock mechanics, this unit prepares students for more advanced geotechnical investigations, design tasks and software implementations of soil and rock mechanics.  Students will have practical opportunities to apply their knowledge of basic rock and soil mechanics through experiencing first-hand the testing requirements that characterize rock and soil materials and underpin engineering design.
subject or unit description 10: This unit provides students with the capabilities needed to select an appropriate mining method, together with associated equipment, technology and infrastructure, for a given resource mineralisation and location. The unit presents the principles, design and application of major surface and underground mining methods, including consideration of cost and productivity aspects, safety implications, environmental and social management issues, and other risks. The unit also covers equipment selection and infrastructure and technology requirements, including emerging technologies such as automation and remote operation. Students will engage with mining operations-related problems using authentic data sets and will be required to participate in up to 2 days of fieldwork activities.

Faculty: WASM: Minerals, Energy and Chemical Engineering (WASM-MECE)
Prerequiste_1:
Writing
6.0, Speaking
6.0, Reading
6.0, Listening
6.0, Overall band score
6.0
Description: Metallurgical engineers mostly work in converting raw metals and minerals into more useable formats, such as converting iron ore and coal into steel. They extract, refine and recycle metals and minerals that are used in many areas of everyday life, including energy production, food production, housing and transportation.
Career outcomes: Metallurgist, Hydrometallurgist, Metallurgical engineer, Minerals engineer, Process control specialist, Process engineer, Process mineralogy specialist, Pyrometallurgy specialist
Remarks: Curtin requires all applicants to demonstrate proficiency in English. Specific English requirements for this course are outlined in the IELTS table below.
Subject or unit name 2: CHEM1000 (v.1) Principles and Processes in Chemistry
Subject or unit name 8: CHEM1002 (v.1) Reactivity and Function in Chemistry

Finally the students will be introduced to vapour-liquid equilibria and chemical equilibria and will learn how to perform equilibrium calculations to predict the results of chemical reactions.
subject or unit description 6: In Process Mass Transfer, students will learn the fundamental theory and introductory practical applications of separation processes. The fundamental theory they will study includes molecular diffusion, convective mass transfer, interphase mass transfer, the two-film model, film and overall mass transfer coefficients and vapour-liquid equilibrium. Mass transfer theory is used to design and analyse unit operations for separation processes. These include flash and continuous distillation, gas absorption and stripping, solvent extraction, solid leaching and humidification. The methods used to study the unit operations are material balances for stage and continuous contact processes, McCabe-Thiele design methods, and packed tower design.
subject or unit description 7: A review of the basic principles of mineralogy, including crystal systems and physical properties. Introduction to crystal chemistry and the concept of unit cells. Solid solution in minerals. A survey of the composition and structure of the common ore minerals - native metals, oxides and sulphides. Analytical methods for ore minerals, including x-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), electron microbe and SIMS (Secondary Ion Mass Spectroscopy). A review of the mineralogy and textures of the common ore deposit types, with special emphasis on how the mineralogy and textures impact on ore processing.
subject or unit description 8: This unit is designed for students who have passed CHEM1000 Principles and Processes in Chemistry or CHEM1001 Biological Chemistry. This unit will prepare you for a wide array of future careers by illustrating how an understanding of reactivity and function assists understanding biological, medicinal, geological and industrial processes. It will provide you with the skills to predict reactions of common functional groups by demonstrating how the mechanistic process gives the outcomes of new, but related reactions, including reactions of relevance to your chosen discipline. Chemical reactions occur over a very wide range of timescales and the ability to measure and predict the rates of reaction, particularly as they are influenced by a number of factors, will display how this has direct influence on your everyday life. Finally, dynamic systems in biology, medicine, industry and nature will illustrate the importance of chemical equilibria.
subject or unit description 9: Compressible and incompressible flow in pipes; Choked flow; Gas/Liquid flow; Flow patterns in horizontal pipes; Energy loss calculation; Vertical flow; Fluid and particle system; Single particle in a fluid; Multiple particles systems; Porous flow; Introduction to the properties of porous media; Concurrent and Counter-current flow; Filtration; Introduction to filtration process; Incompressible and compressible cake; Filtration equipment Theory of sedimentation; Batch and continuous settler design; Flocculation; compression; settling of drops and bubbles; Fluidisation; Liquid-solid, Gas-solid systems; Centrifuge and Cyclone design  Slurry transport; Pheumatic transport
subject or unit description 10: This unit covers the theory and practice of reaction equilibrium, reaction kinetics and the interpretation of batch reactor data. Students are introduced to the design of batch and continuous reactors, reactor geometrics, ideal tubular, mixed and staged reactors for single and multiple reactions. They will learn how to interpret laboratory data and use data analytics to deduce rate laws and reaction mechanism. They will investigate thermal and pressure effects, isothermal and non-isothermal homogeneous reactions, and deviations from ideal reactor models. Heterogeneous reaction systems, including solid catalysed reactions, and residence time distributions will be analysed.

Faculty: School of Civil and Mechanical Engineering
Prerequiste_1:
Writing
6.0, Speaking
6.0, Reading
6.0, Listening
6.0, Overall band score
6.0
Description: Mechatronic engineers work at the interface of mechanical devices and electronic control systems.
Career outcomes: Mechatronic engineer, Mechanical engineer, Automation engineer, Computer systems engineer, Data scientist
Remarks: Curtin requires all applicants to demonstrate proficiency in English. Specific English requirements for this course are outlined in the IELTS table below.
subject or unit description 1: This unit will build on students' calculus and linear algebra skills to consider a range of techniques applicable to engineering. Students will cover vector functions, eigenvalues and eigenvectors. This unit will also cover multivariable calculus including differential operators and repeated integrals. Students will consider first and second order differential equations and be introduced to Fourier Series and Laplace Transforms, and their various applications.
subject or unit description 2: Structure of mechatronic systems; Sensors and actuators; Embedded microcontroller programming, compiling, simulation and download; Binary and bitwise programming; Timers and interrupts; Darlington drivers; Protection diodes; H-bridge design; Voltage regulated power supply design; Servomotor control; Stepper motor control; PWM control of DC motors; Analog-to-Digital converters; Keypads and LCD displays; Students will work in teams to program and build a functional controller for a mobile robot to be used in a competition.
subject or unit description 3: Introduction to basic properties of dynamics, problem formulation and solution concepts, coordinate systems, planar motion of rigid bodies, Newton's Second Law, free body diagrams, static and dynamic friction, inclined plane motion, relative motion, velocity and acceleration diagrams, and rotating and reciprocating components. Rigid body motion with applied forces and torques. Mass moments of inertia, parallel axis theorem, simple and complex bodies, thin plates and experimental measurement. Introduction to mechanical power transfer systems including gears (fixed axis and epicyclic), belt drives (flat and Vee belts), Hooke's joints, and friction clutches (disk, cone and centrifugal).
subject or unit description 4: Review of Direct Current (DC) resistive circuits and circuit theorems.  Nodal Voltage and Mesh Current methods of analysis.  Introduction to Alternate Current (AC) circuits and coupling circuits (mutual inductance and transformers).  Balanced and unbalanced 3-phase circuits and power calculations.  Frequency responses of Resistive-Inductive-Capacitive (R-L-C) circuits.  Transient circuit analysis, First and second orders.  Use of Laplace Transform in Circuit Analysis.  Operational amplifiers and Active filter circuits.
subject or unit description 5: This unit focuses on digital design and computer architecture. It provides grounding on the foundations of digital logic design from the perspective of a Microprocessor without Interlocked Pipeline Storage (MIPS) processor architecture. Basic techniques on Boolean algebra and minimisation are covered to design combinational circuits and sequential systems which are building blocks to a MIPS. Using Electronic Design Automation (EDA) tools and Very High Speed Integrated Circuit Hardware Description Language (VHDL) and examining assembly programs, students will be able to gain further understanding in the complex world of computer architecture design.
subject or unit description 6: This unit introduces students to the C programming language and the related concepts and tools used to design, implement, test and debug C programs. Topics covered include: C Fundamentals. Functions and program structure. Designing programs with derived types. Pointers. Abstract data types. Strings, streams and input/output (I/O). Dynamic memory allocation and C programming utilitiers for program construction and diagnosis.
subject or unit description 7: The course will cover continuous-time and discrete-time signals, specifically their mathematical representations, properties and classifications, such as power and energy signals.  Special attention is devoted to Linear time-invariant systems, where concepts such as impulse response, convolution are developed. The course also cover the Fourier series representation of periodic signals, which leads to continuous-time Fourier transform (and discrete-time Fourier transform), Laplace transform and Sampling theorem. Students will be introduced to Matlab.
subject or unit description 8:
Topics of modelling, experimentation and simulation using problem based learning to solve problems in the context of a mechatronic system. The tasks which students complete in this unit provide opportunities to solve “open”, rather than “closed” problems.  The “open” problem of this unit is to develop a model that predicts the time for a simple mechatronic vehicle to ascend an incline.  The syllabus requires the student to actively participate and seek out “better” answers.
Solving open mechatronic engineering problems and using system principles: hierarchies and abstractions. 
Problem analysis, design and creation of models and experiments. Reoccuring Modelling concepts: elements and governing equations.
Engineering Communications. 
Experiment theory and design to determine stall torque and torque-speed characteristics of a DC motor including applications of Newton’s Laws to dynamic systems.
Applications of electromagnetics and efficiency concepts. 
Use of computer tools Excel and Simulink for modelling and analysis. 
System response: concepts of transient and steady state behaviour. 
Results anaylsis.
subject or unit description 9: This unit deals with the fundamentals of engineering economics. The key elements are interpretation of financial statements. The focus is on depreciation, taxes, time value of money, net present value (NPV), Minimum Attractive Rate of Return (MARR) and the Internal Rate of Return (IRR). This unit also covers at inflation, the cost of capital, Debt and Equity and Weighted Average Cost of Capital (WACC).This unit also covers the basics of contract law, Quality Management, Procurement and Project Risk Management using Decision Tree analysis. The fundamentals of project management include planning, monitoring, scope, cost control, integration, project life cycle, Work Breakdown Structures (WBS), Critical path analysis and project termination.
subject or unit description 10: Pneumatics actuators, gripper technology, control values and pneumatic circuit representation. Sequential control systems. Programmable logic controllers (PLC). Sequential control system representation, logic analysis and PLC programming. Sensor technology for sequence control, optical, capacitive, inductive and magnetic. Computer simulation of a programmable pneumatic positioning system.

Description: Mechanical engineers analyse and develop technological systems that involve motion. They help society harness the energy and forces that exist in nature.
Career outcomes: Mechanical engineer, Aeronautical engineer, Mechatronic engineer
Remarks: Curtin requires all applicants to demonstrate proficiency in English. Specific English requirements for this course are outlined in the IELTS table below.
Subject or unit name 5: MCEN2000 (v.1) Fundamentals of Strength of Materials
subject or unit description 1: This unit deals with the principles, rules and standards that govern the creation and interpretation of engineering drawings. Students learn and apply the theory and concept of orthographic projection to describe three dimensional objects and concepts two dimensionally. Through the study of drawing standards, conventions and abbreviations, students develop their capacity to produce and interpret multi-view drawings that include auxiliary and sectional views. Students also learn and use CAD software to produce detail and assembly drawings.
subject or unit description 2: This unit will build on students' calculus and linear algebra skills to consider a range of techniques applicable to engineering. Students will cover vector functions, eigenvalues and eigenvectors. This unit will also cover multivariable calculus including differential operators and repeated integrals. Students will consider first and second order differential equations and be introduced to Fourier Series and Laplace Transforms, and their various applications.
subject or unit description 3: Introduction (basic properties of fluids), flow fields (steady/unsteady flow, streamlines), velocity profile (Couette flow) and Newton's law of viscosity, Reynolds number. Hydrostatics, control-volume analysis - mass conservation and momentum equation and applications of CV analysis. Bernoulli equation, measurement of pressure, flow speed and volumetric flow rate, and applications of Bernoulli equation (Froude propeller theory). One-dimensional energy equation, laminar flow in pipes and channels, laminar-to-turbulent transition, turbulent flow in pipes, index and logarithmic laws, wall-roughness, Moody chart, hydraulic grade lines, boundary layers (laminar and turbulent), drag, dimensional analysis, dynamic similarity, pump types and characterisation.
subject or unit description 4: Introduction to basic properties of dynamics, problem formulation and solution concepts, coordinate systems, planar motion of rigid bodies, Newton's Second Law, free body diagrams, static and dynamic friction, inclined plane motion, relative motion, velocity and acceleration diagrams, and rotating and reciprocating components. Rigid body motion with applied forces and torques. Mass moments of inertia, parallel axis theorem, simple and complex bodies, thin plates and experimental measurement. Introduction to mechanical power transfer systems including gears (fixed axis and epicyclic), belt drives (flat and Vee belts), Hooke's joints, and friction clutches (disk, cone and centrifugal).
subject or unit description 5: Introduction for Strength of Materials. Normal stresses and strains. Shear stresses and strains. Hooke’s law in tension and shear, Poisson’s ratio. The concepts of allowable stresses, factor of safety. Computation of changes in length of axially loaded members, uniform and nonuniform bars. Statically indeterminate structures. Formulation of the torsion formula and its applications. Stresses and strains in pure shear. Types of beams and different boundary conditions. Construction of shear force and bending diagrams. Formulation and applications of flexure formula based on the Euler beam theory. Design of beams for bending stresses. Formulation of the shear formula. Design of beams for shear stresses. Centroids and second moments of plane sections. Parallel axis theorem. Analysis of stresses and strains for plane stress problems. Mohr’s circle for plane problems. Thin-walled pressure vessels. Combined loadings. Deflections of beams, the integration methods.
subject or unit description 6: Sustainable development is about forms of progress that combine economic development, social advancement, environmental protection and is widely recognised by the public, private and civic sectors as one of the key challenges for the 21st century. Deals with the contribution of engineering to the development and implementation of sustainable solutions.  Introduction to the sustainable development agenda. Practical methods and tools for development and implementation of sustainable solutions which complement generic 'good engineering and management practice'. Introduction to sustainable technology development.
subject or unit description 7: Introduction to Manufacturing Processes and Safety, Standards and Specifications, Traditional Shaping and Machining Processes, Production Planning, Computer Numerical Control (CNC) Machining, Primary Forming Processes, Secondary Forming Processes, Joining Processes.
subject or unit description 8: The uses of First and Second moments of area, bending moments and Shear force diagrams, Stress and curvature in straight beams due to bending moments, Stresses in curved beams due to bending moments, Basic design of bolted and welded joints, Design of drum, disc and band brakes, Design of clutches, Design of power screws, Application of the principles of virtual work to equilibrium and stability.
subject or unit description 9: The objective of this unit is to learn the basic concepts of thermodynamics and apply them to relevant mechanical engineering situations. Initially, students will learn the fundamental concepts of thermodynamic systems and control volumes to analyse closed and open systems. This will be followed by the derivation of mathematical relations for various thermodynamic properties of pure substances and ideal gases. Analysis of the interactions between work and heat flow leads into the First Law of Thermodynamics, considered for both closed systems (non-flow energy equation) and open systems (steady flow energy equation). Finally, students will be introduced to the Second Law of Thermodynamics using the concepts of heat engines and heat pumps, considering reversibility and irreversibility of processes, the Clausius Inequality, entropy and measure of irreversibility.
subject or unit description 10: Three-phase circuits. Reactive power and power factor correction. Transformers. Single and three-phase induction motors. Electric motors: starting, speed control, and motor selection. Condition monitoring in process plants.

Description: Industrial and systems engineering focuses on the design and optimisation of a whole system rather than individual components. Industrial and system engineers explore problems in their entirety to create holistic solutions and processes for complex projects.
Career outcomes: Manufacturing engineer, Production engineer, Data modeller, Logistics specialist, Material handling, maintenance or scheduling specialist, Plant manager, Process control analyst, Process improvement specialist, Quality controller
Remarks: Curtin requires all applicants to demonstrate proficiency in English. Specific English requirements for this course are outlined in the IELTS table below.
Subject or unit name 1: MCEN2000 (v.1) Fundamentals of Strength of Materials
Subject or unit name 7: STAT1005 (v.1) Introduction to Probability and Data Analysis
subject or unit description 1: Introduction for Strength of Materials. Normal stresses and strains. Shear stresses and strains. Hooke’s law in tension and shear, Poisson’s ratio. The concepts of allowable stresses, factor of safety. Computation of changes in length of axially loaded members, uniform and nonuniform bars. Statically indeterminate structures. Formulation of the torsion formula and its applications. Stresses and strains in pure shear. Types of beams and different boundary conditions. Construction of shear force and bending diagrams. Formulation and applications of flexure formula based on the Euler beam theory. Design of beams for bending stresses. Formulation of the shear formula. Design of beams for shear stresses. Centroids and second moments of plane sections. Parallel axis theorem. Analysis of stresses and strains for plane stress problems. Mohr’s circle for plane problems. Thin-walled pressure vessels. Combined loadings. Deflections of beams, the integration methods.

Students also learn and use CAD software to produce detail and assembly drawings.

Students will cover vector functions, eigenvalues and eigenvectors. This unit will also cover multivariable calculus including differential operators and repeated integrals. Students will consider first and second order differential equations and be introduced to Fourier Series and Laplace Transforms, and their various applications.

Rigid body motion with applied forces and torques. Mass moments of inertia, parallel axis theorem, simple and complex bodies, thin plates and experimental measurement. Introduction to mechanical power transfer systems including gears (fixed axis and epicyclic), belt drives (flat and Vee belts), Hooke's joints, and friction clutches (disk, cone and centrifugal).
subject or unit description 5: The course will cover continuous-time and discrete-time signals, specifically their mathematical representations, properties and classifications, such as power and energy signals.  Special attention is devoted to Linear time-invariant systems, where concepts such as impulse response, convolution are developed. The course also cover the Fourier series representation of periodic signals, which leads to continuous-time Fourier transform (and discrete-time Fourier transform), Laplace transform and Sampling theorem. Students will be introduced to Matlab.
subject or unit description 6: The uses of First and Second moments of area, bending moments and Shear force diagrams, Stress and curvature in straight beams due to bending moments, Stresses in curved beams due to bending moments, Basic design of bolted and welded joints, Design of drum, disc and band brakes, Design of clutches, Design of power screws, Application of the principles of virtual work to equilibrium and stability.
subject or unit description 7: This unit is an introduction to methods of statistical analysis and their role in scientific inference - drawing conclusions about the world using data. It begins with an introduction to probability, which provides a foundation for understanding randomness, uncertainty, chance, and most important of all, for statistical inference. We start with a gentle introduction to definitions of probability and probability models, and then go on to discuss probability distributions, and tools and techniques that can be used to model a wide range of phenomena, as well as those that are useful in statistical inference. In the second part of the unit, we discuss descriptive statistics and inferential statistics. Throughout, we will emphasize that how data are collected determines the nature of the conclusions that we are entitled to draw from any study. Students will be introduced to the R language statistical environment, which they will use for exploring, displaying, and analysing data, and for carrying out and reporting the results of statistical inference.
subject or unit description 8: Linear Algebra introduces students to linear techniques and their transformation properties. These techniques are often used in engineering, physics, science, computing and economics. The unit comprises four parts. In the first part, the students are introduced to the concept of vector spaces, subspaces, linear dependence, independence, span, basis, dimension and coordination of vectors. In the second part, students learn about linear transformation, inner products, inner product spaces, orthogonal and orthonormal bases. In the third part, students practice techniques dealing with matrix decomposition and generalized inverse. In the last part, students learn about linear systems of differential equations.
subject or unit description 9: Introduction to Manufacturing Processes and Safety, Standards and Specifications, Traditional Shaping and Machining Processes, Production Planning, Computer Numerical Control (CNC) Machining, Primary Forming Processes, Secondary Forming Processes, Joining Processes.
subject or unit description 10: Part 1: CNC machining introduction and classification of CNC machines and safety procedures. CNC Programming instructions. Programming with canned cycles. Programming with macro statements. Component manufacture by use of CAD/CAM. Part 2: Material Removal Processes. Introduction to cutting tool theory. Theory of chip formation in metal machining. Force relationship and Merchant’s analysis. Power and energy relationships in machining. Cutting temperature, Cutting fluids. Broaching. Gear Manufacturing, Gear Measurement. Part 3: Advanced machining processes. Surface treatments. Micro technology, Rapid Prototyping. Powder Metallurgy.

Description: Civil engineers design and construct our infrastructure. They are key members of teams involved in the design and construction of buildings, bridges, roads, highways, harbours, dams, irrigation and water supplies, municipal infrastructure and other large projects.
Career outcomes: Civil engineer, Design engineer, Site engineer, Structural engineer, Building contractor
Remarks: Curtin requires all applicants to demonstrate proficiency in English. Specific English requirements for this course are outlined in the IELTS table below.
Subject or unit name 2: CVEN2000 (v.1) Civil Engineering Drawing and Surveying
Subject or unit name 3: STEN2005 (v.1) Structural Analysis of Determinate Structures
Subject or unit name 5: WSEN2000 (v.1) Water Quality and Resources Engineering
Subject or unit name 8: STEN2006 (v.1) Structural Analysis of Indeterminate Structures
subject or unit description 1: Strength, behaviour and durability properties, production and protection of commonly utilised Civil Engineering materials (Concrete, Steel, Timber, Asphalt and Geotextiles) are examined, along with methods of calculating stresses and strains in materials under different loading conditions. Geometric properties (Area, Centroid, I, Z, S) are determined in order to calculate normal and shear stresses due to applied Axial, Bending, Shear and Torsion actions. Material properties (E, G, Poisson’s Ratio) are examined and utilised in order to determine normal and shear strains due to normal and shear stresses. The basic relationships between normal stress and strain are expanded upon with the investigation into general beam equations, general strain equations, compatibility, composite beam behaviour and plastic behaviour of beams. Shear stresses and strains due to shear forces and torsion in circular shafts are introduced. Biaxial Stress systems, and the combination of normal and shear stresses, are analysed using Mohr’s circles of stress and strain, and stress transformation equations. Combined stresses due to combined loadings complete the stress and strain analysis component of the unit.
subject or unit description 3: This unit introduces classical methods of analysis to enable students to assess, quantify and communicate an understanding of Statically Determinate Structures’ behaviours. The syllabus includes types of structures and loads, analysis of statically determinate structures (including beams, frames and trusses), deflection elastic beam theory, deflections using and geometrical and energy methods, and influence lines for statically determinate structures.
subject or unit description 4: Introduction (basic properties of fluids), flow fields (steady/unsteady flow, streamlines), velocity profile (Couette flow) and Newton's law of viscosity, Reynolds number. Hydrostatics, control-volume analysis - mass conservation and momentum equation and applications of CV analysis. Bernoulli equation, measurement of pressure, flow speed and volumetric flow rate, and applications of Bernoulli equation (Froude propeller theory). One-dimensional energy equation, laminar flow in pipes and channels, laminar-to-turbulent transition, turbulent flow in pipes, index and logarithmic laws, wall-roughness, Moody chart, hydraulic grade lines, boundary layers (laminar and turbulent), drag, dimensional analysis, dynamic similarity, pump types and characterisation.
subject or unit description 5: This unit introduces the concepts and methods of analysing water quality, including chemical, biological and physical quality measures. It will introduce water resources, comprising identification and analysis of common types of water sources. Students will evaluate typical qualities, variabilities, applications, and indicative treatment methods of water. The legislation of water quality, including drinking water guidelines will be analysed as to its principles and purpose. Identification and basic analysis of the principles and methods of conventional water and wastewater treatment recycling and re-use will be addressed.
subject or unit description 6: Sustainable development is about forms of progress that combine economic development, social advancement, environmental protection and is widely recognised by the public, private and civic sectors as one of the key challenges for the 21st century. Deals with the contribution of engineering to the development and implementation of sustainable solutions.  Introduction to the sustainable development agenda. Practical methods and tools for development and implementation of sustainable solutions which complement generic 'good engineering and management practice'. Introduction to sustainable technology development.
subject or unit description 7: This unit introduces students to geotechnical engineering. Students will learn about engineering geology and the physical properties and classification of soils as a geotechnical engineering material. Students will also develop an understanding of the fundamental concepts of stresses, seepage and compaction in soil masses.
subject or unit description 8: This unit introduces classical methods of analysis to enable students to assess, quantify and communicate an understanding of Statically Indeterminate Structures’ behaviours. The syllabus includes analysis of statically indeterminate structures by the force method, displacement method, slope deflection method and moment distribution method, influence lines for statically indeterminate structures and application of key concepts of compatibility, flexibility and stiffness.
subject or unit description 9: The unit is on the analysis of stresses in structural elements for different types of actions. It contains stresses for flexure, shear and torsional actions in solid and thin walled sections, stresses for unsymmetrical bending, combinations and transformation of stresses, stress and strain tensors and failure analysis.
subject or unit description 10: This unit is on the analysis of statically indeterminate structures by the matrix methods, computer software and approximate approaches. The contents include stiffness and flexibility concepts of truss and beam members, procedures of full and direct stiffness methods applied to trusses, beams and frames, flexibility methods applied to trusses, beams and frames, self-straining of structures, analysis using commercial software, and analysis by approximate methods.
