Description: More Indigenous professionals are needed in the health and community management and development industries to work within their communities to provide holistic healthcare frameworks.
Career outcomes: NULL
Remarks: Curtin requires all applicants to demonstrate proficiency in English. Specific English requirements for this course are outlined in the IELTS table below.
Subject or unit name 1: INDH2002 (v.2) Indigenous Public Health and Health Promotion
Subject or unit name 2: INCD2005 (v.1) Indigenous Australian Organisational Practice and Management Skills
Subject or unit name 3: INDH2001 (v.1) Indigenous Australian Health Project Management
Subject or unit name 4: INDH2014 (v.1) Australian Health and Political Systems
Subject or unit name 5: PUBH2004 (v.1) Indigenous Australian Professional Practice and Leadership
Subject or unit name 6: INDH2004 (v.1) Indigenous Australian Health Project Evaluation
Subject or unit name 7: INCD2013 (v.1) Laws and Legislation in Indigenous Australian Community Development
Subject or unit name 8: INDH2003 (v.1) Indigenous Australian Health Project Implementation
Subject or unit name 9: INCD3009 (v.1) Research Planning Processes for Indigenous Australians
subject or unit description 1: The examination of Indigenous and non-Indigenous health promotion theories, models and strategies forms the bases of understanding the development of best practice in health promotion. Investigations of health education, health and social determinants, learning styles, principles of learning and values, beliefs and attitude identification in an Indigenous context is significant to developing and implementing improved health promotion outcomes and health behaviour.
subject or unit description 2: Examination of government and non-government health organisations including structure, function and management models. Indigenous management models and organisational governance including Indigenous Ways of Working and Federal and State corporation acts. Developing vision statements and strategic planning concepts at an organisational level.
subject or unit description 3: Development of a health project using Primary Health Care ethics, principles and practice in an Indigenous context. Health problem identification and needs analysis, negotiation and consultation, identification and engagement with stakeholders and potential impacts of the project. Peer review and Professional Development Group processes.
subject or unit description 4: This unit involves the exploration of the Australian political system including separation of powers, levels of government and political process. Through the examination of major state and federal health systems and policies the unit analyses the impact of the Australian political system and Indigenous political representation, sovereignty and self-determination for Indigenous Australians.
subject or unit description 5: Development of professional behaviour and ethics as an Indigenous health professional in multi-disciplinary settings. Examination of Indigenous leadership in the context of health care including theoretical approaches to leadership and contemporary issues in relation to health care. Promotion of Indigenous self-determination and governance.
subject or unit description 6: Evaluate project to complete project management cycle. Monitor and review project outcomes in a culturally appropriate ways to maintain health promotion in Indigenous communities. Review role as an Indigenous health practitioner based on health promotion and project management principles, and Indigenous Terms of Reference.
subject or unit description 7: This unit examines laws and legislation that govern community organisations for both internal and external operations. Students will be introduced to areas of law that significantly impact upon community development and management, and will apply this knowledge in a discrete community context.
subject or unit description 8: Principles of project monitoring and reviewing in readiness for project implementation. Review of project logistics, activities and resources. Identification and management of potential risks to project implementation. Peer review and Professional Development Group processes.
subject or unit description 9: Plan and situate the evaluation research project within a broader socio-political context including Indigenous settings. Explore the relationship between evaluation, community development and action research utilising ethical research practices. Develop and integrate evaluation research concepts to Indigenous community practice frameworks. Establish a critical reference group and other stakeholders using culturally appropriate methods to facilitate collaboration to initiate positive change.
subject or unit description 10: Facilitate participatory inquiry, learning and education in Indigenous settings using culturally appropriate methods and processes. Provide background information about local issues to engage community members in the learning and development process. Develop, integrate and apply conceptual frameworks and skills related to learning about local issues in a community setting.

Prerequiste_1:
Writing
6.0, Speaking
6.0, Reading

6.0, Overall band score
6.5
Description: The Public Health Honours is a specialised year of study for those students who have demonstrated a high level of academic achievement in their undergraduate degree.
Career outcomes: NULL
Remarks: Curtin requires all applicants to demonstrate proficiency in English. Specific English requirements for this course are outlined in the IELTS table below.
Subject or unit name 2: MEDS4003 (v.1) Principles of Epidemiology and Biostatistics
subject or unit description 1: Fundamental competencies to enable students to develop an appreciation of the ethics and principles of research and research design; critically appraise and interpret scientific literature; as well as develop skills in planning and writing a research proposal.
subject or unit description 2: This unit provides an introduction to the core skills in epidemiology and statistical concepts, their use and relevance in health research. Topics covered include: quantitative and qualitative research methods, study design, characteristics of a good research question, definition and selection of study population and participants, reliability and validity of data, statistical methods and the use of statistical software. The emphasis is on practical enabling students to conduct independent public health research.
subject or unit description 3: A continuation of attributes learnt from Public Health Honours Preparation, students will develop competencies in the research process and interpretation of data from their research project. Students will develop skills in: oral presentations communicating the results and significance of their research; preparing a research article and dissertation; as well as responding to examiners’ comments.
subject or unit description 4: This unit is a follow up unit from MEDS4003 Principles of Epidemiology and Biostatistics. Statistical and epidemiological methods commonly used in health research will be applied using real examples and case scenarios. There will be elements of critical appraisal on the methods, evidence-based recommendation and knowledge translation.

Faculty: Centre for Aboriginal Studies
Description: This Major provides students with the skills and knowledge necessary to work in Indigenous Mental Health. It aims to empower and strengthen the well-being of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities through a holistic, multi-disciplinary approach that encompasses traditional healing practices in the context of mental health best care and treatment modalities. This Major will provide students with comprehensive mental health strategies, skills, knowledge and treatment methodologies to engage and inter-relate with Aboriginal community mental health patients who may be suffering with a mental health illness.
Career outcomes: NULL
Remarks: At Curtin, we understand that everyone’s study journey has been different.

Faculty: School of Molecular and Life Sciences (MLS)
Description: Medical Imaging graduates work with a range of sophisticated diagnostic imaging modalities including computed and digital radiography, fluoroscopy, computed tomography, magnetic resonance imaging, mammography and angiography equipment. They produce images which are used to confirm or exclude a medical diagnosis, to advise on a treatment or illness, monitor patient progress, or provide medical screening. A genuine interest in managing a wide range of patients and their needs is an important function of the professional.
Career outcomes: NULL
Remarks: At Curtin, we understand that everyone’s study journey has been different.
subject or unit description 1: First period of the clinical experience necessary to adapt in-house learning to application in the workplace. General clinical practice with emphasis on patients who are ambulant and have no barriers to communication.
subject or unit description 2: The technological features of 2D and 3D imaging modalities used in medical radiation practice (computed tomography, magnetic resonance imaging, mammography, ultrasound and emission tomography) will be discussed. The theory will focus on instrumentation, image formation, clinical applications and regulations/standards. Concepts relating to digital image generation will be covered. Basic technological features of health information systems will also be discussed
subject or unit description 3: Positioning theory, patient care, communication, radiographic or surface or applied anatomy, commonly encountered pathology or trauma, image acquisition and interpretation relevant to the intermediate beginner practitioner.
subject or unit description 4: 2D axial, multiplanar reformatted sections (coronal, sagittal and oblique) and 3D (Computed Tomography [CT] angiography and Magnetic Resonance [MR] angiography of vascular structures) images of the head, neck, vertebral column, the extremities, chest, abdomen and pelvis using CT, MR and Ultrasound images.
subject or unit description 5: Further development of clinical experience, extending the application of in house learning to include skeletal components of the head. Adaptation of examination knowledge according to a range of different patient types and age groups, whether with normal findings, pathological and traumatic injury.
subject or unit description 6: Positioning theory, patient care, communication, radiographic or surface or applied anatomy, commonly encountered pathology or trauma, image acquisition and interpretation relevant to the advanced beginner practitioner.
subject or unit description 7: The more advanced technological developments of computed tomography and magnetic resonance imaging modalities will be examined, along with supplementary and additional instruments used in medical radiation practice (portable, mobile and dental X-rays, fluoroscopy, angiography, and nuclear medicine). The theory covered will extend students' understanding of the equipment and/or systems, including their design, construction, operation, clinical applications, and relevant regulations and standards. Image post-processing and visualisation tools will be applied to the management and manipulation of 3D datasets for diagnostic applications. Safety and quality assurance requirements will also be considered, including those related to the use of contrast media.
subject or unit description 8: The section of introductory pathology covers disease and body defence mechanisms, carcinogenesis and neoplasia; pathological effects of ionizing radiation. The section of systematic pathology deals with the musculoskeletal, respiratory and cardiovascular systems. Various 2D and 3D imaging modalities including general x-ray, ultrasound, computed tomography and magnetic resonance imaging that are commonly used in clinical practice for making diagnosis are presented and compared. The evaluation of medical imaging evidence of disease processes on images enables medical imaging technologists to provide an informed opinion to a medical practitioner.
subject or unit description 9: Progression of clinical experience with a focus on extending skills in general areas of radiographic practice and contrast study examinations. Participation in the peer support program.
subject or unit description 10: In this unit, students will critically consider their professional obligations to patients, the community, their profession and themselves. Engagement with authentic scenarios will enable students to explore ethical and legal practice, psycho-socially supportive care and professional responsiveness to patients’ needs, Students will explore practice and problem-solving in the interprofessional team.

Faculty: School of Molecular and Life Sciences (MLS)
Description: Radiation therapists play an integral role in the treatment, care and management of patients undergoing radiation therapy treatment, primarily in treating a range of cancer types. Graduates must balance a genuine interest in patients and their welfare with the technical requirements necessary to undertake radiation therapy procedures. Radiation therapy increasingly incorporates high end imaging technologies as integral requirements of patient treatment.
Career outcomes: NULL
Remarks: At Curtin, we understand that everyone’s study journey has been different.
subject or unit description 1: This unit provides authentic radiation therapy professional practice experience in the clinical setting, at the level appropriate for the beginning reflective professional.
subject or unit description 2: The technological features of 2D and 3D imaging modalities used in medical radiation practice (computed tomography, magnetic resonance imaging, mammography, ultrasound and emission tomography) will be discussed. The theory will focus on instrumentation, image formation, clinical applications and regulations/standards. Concepts relating to digital image generation will be covered. Basic technological features of health information systems will also be discussed
subject or unit description 3: This unit provides a comprehensive development of the theoretical knowledge and practical skills underpinning intermediate beginning radiation therapy practice, including the principles, technology, patient positioning and approaches associated with simulation, planning and treatment. This unit provides further development of the intermediate beginning radiation therapist’s capacity for person-centred care, effective communication, safe and ethical practice, and reflective thinking.
subject or unit description 4: 2D axial, multiplanar reformatted sections (coronal, sagittal and oblique) and 3D (Computed Tomography [CT] angiography and Magnetic Resonance [MR] angiography of vascular structures) images of the head, neck, vertebral column, the extremities, chest, abdomen and pelvis using CT, MR and Ultrasound images.
subject or unit description 5: This unit provides authentic radiation therapy professional practice experience in the clinical setting, at the level appropriate for the intermediate beginning reflective professional. Students will have the opportunity to develop their capacity for mentoring.
subject or unit description 6: This unit provides a comprehensive development of the theoretical knowledge and practical skills underpinning intermediate/advanced beginning radiation therapy practice, including the principles, technology, patient positioning and approaches associated with simulation, planning and treatment. This unit provides further development of the intermediate/advanced beginning radiation therapist’s capacity for person-centred care, effective communication, safe and ethical practice, and reflective thinking.
subject or unit description 7: This unit will cover the biological effects of ionising and non-ionising radiation at the cellular level and the resulting effects on organs, tissues and the whole body. Students will gain an in-depth knowledge on mechanisms of repair to biological damage; systemic and total body responses to early/late effects of radiation; hereditary effects; and effects on the embryo and foetus. Students will then apply this fundamental knowledge to critically consider the principles of fractionation and the justifications for the various treatment schedules.
subject or unit description 8: The section of introductory pathology covers disease and body defence mechanisms, carcinogenesis and neoplasia; pathological effects of ionizing radiation. The section of systematic pathology deals with the musculoskeletal, respiratory and cardiovascular systems. Various 2D and 3D imaging modalities including general x-ray, ultrasound, computed tomography and magnetic resonance imaging that are commonly used in clinical practice for making diagnosis are presented and compared. The evaluation of medical imaging evidence of disease processes on images enables medical imaging technologists to provide an informed opinion to a medical practitioner.
subject or unit description 9: This unit provides authentic radiation therapy professional practice experience in the clinical setting, at the level appropriate for the intermediate/advanced beginning reflective professional. Students will have the opportunity to advance their capacity for mentoring.
subject or unit description 10: In this unit, students will critically consider their professional obligations to patients, the community, their profession and themselves. Engagement with authentic scenarios will enable students to explore ethical and legal practice, psycho-socially supportive care and professional responsiveness to patients’ needs, Students will explore practice and problem-solving in the interprofessional team.

Courses: Indigenous Australian Mental Health Principles and Practice
Faculty: Centre for Aboriginal Studies
Description: This Major provides students with the skills and knowledge necessary to work as an Indigenous Mental Health Practitioner. It aims to empower and strengthen the well-being of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities through a holistic, multi-disciplinary approach that encompasses traditional healing practices in the context of mental health best care and treatment modalities. This Major will provide students with comprehensive mental health strategies, skills, knowledge and treatment methodologies to engage and inter-relate with Aboriginal community mental health patients who may be suffering with a mental health illness.
Career outcomes: NULL
Remarks: At Curtin, we understand that everyone’s study journey has been different.
Subject or unit name 1: INDH2011 (v.1) Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Mental Health First Aid
Subject or unit name 6: PUBH2004 (v.1) Indigenous Australian Professional Practice and Leadership
Subject or unit name 8: INDH2013 (v.1) Psychopharmacology in Indigenous Mental Health
Subject or unit name 9: INDH3005 (v.1) Principles and Practices of Counselling
subject or unit description 1: This unit provides students with skills to assist a person who may be developing a mental health crisis. The unit also explores Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander social and emotional wellbeing, mental health concerns within communities and professional health teams, and mental health first aid strategies for working with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities. Unit content also includes: recognising depression, anxiety, gradual onset psychosis, substance misuse, eating disorders, suicidal thoughts and behaviours, panic attacks and severe effects of drug or alcohol use.
subject or unit description 2: An analysis and application of knowledge of common mental health disorders, the signs and symptoms of mood affective disorders including depression, bipolar and anxiety disorders. The association between trans-generational trauma and depression among stolen generation people is also explored. Students critically examine these maladaptive behaviours and categorise them from a mental health perspective that includes concurrent conditions, classification of the disorder and appropriate referral.
subject or unit description 3: An examination of the physical, social and cognitive human developmental milestones from preconception to adulthood. This will also include a consideration of the complications of trauma and adverse childhood experience on these milestones.
subject or unit description 4: An examination of factors that contribute to mental health for Indigenous people from the perspectives of social determinants of health, management of mental health in the family and community, and the application of holistic practice that enables best care and treatment for Indigenous peoples.
subject or unit description 5: This unit examines the foundations and relationship of the brain, the central nervous system structure and function, and cognition. It also examines the relationship between neurophysiology and behaviours, including reference to contemporary addiction theories.
subject or unit description 6: Development of professional behaviour and ethics as an Indigenous health professional in multi-disciplinary settings. Examination of Indigenous leadership in the context of health care including theoretical approaches to leadership and contemporary issues in relation to health care. Promotion of Indigenous self-determination and governance.
subject or unit description 7: Broad outline of the nature, methods, and fields of psychology. Introduction to psychology and methodological issues related to the study of human beings and the relevance of both for interactions with individuals and groups. Introduction to social psychology, personality, development, learning, memory, and motivation.
subject or unit description 8: This unit gives an overview of the uses and dynamics of commonly prescribed medicines for the treatment of mental health disorders. The major families of medications are reviewed along with their biopsychosocial and holistic impacts. More commonly used bush medicines will also be covered.
subject or unit description 9: Exploration of the current theories involved in establishing a successful counselling relationship. This includes the methods used to work professionally, ethically and in support of a safe and secure environment for the client. Students develop an applied understanding of counselling skills, with attention to self-awareness, reflecting the influence of values, attitudes and biases on communication in the counselling space. Students will also develop their knowledge and skills to enable them to conduct a basic interview and counselling session within an observational setting.
subject or unit description 10: This unit explores the theories and strategies for intervention and management within crisis situations. A key focus of this unit is evidence based trauma informed approaches to healing and recovery within an Indigenous Australian historic, generational trauma, context. Students will critically consider the multi-dimensional nature of trauma and the human responses to traumatic experiences. Themes addressed include: self-care, the helper/client relationship, suicide intervention, recovery and aftermath of trauma, crisis related to substance abuse, illness, death and loss, and community programs for crisis intervention.

Courses: Computer Systems and Networking, Information Technology
Faculty: School of Electrical Engineering, Computing and Mathematical Sciences (EECMS)
Prerequiste_1:
Writing
6.0, Speaking
6.0, Reading
6.0, Listening
6.0, Overall band score

Description: This course focuses on computer technology (hardware and software), communications and networking that incorporate Local Area Networks (LANs) and Wide Area Networks (WANs), as well as network management and the Internet of Things.
Career outcomes: Computer programmer, Computer security consultant, Industrial network engineer, IT professional, Network and system administrator, Software engineer / developer, Systems designer, Telecommunications manager

Faculty: School of Management, School of Accounting
Description: Specialise in the development and use of computers and information systems for accounting purposes. You’ll be introduced to a wide range of accounting principles, and learn how to manage, plan, analyse and design the information technologies used in organisations.
Career outcomes: At Curtin, we understand that everyone’s study journey has been different.
Remarks: At Curtin, we understand that everyone’s study journey has been different.
Subject or unit name 3: ISYS2002 (v.1) Introductory Systems Analysis and Design
Subject or unit name 6: ACCT2002 (v.2) Cost Analysis for Decision Making
Subject or unit name 7: ACCT2013 (v.1) Accounting - The Fundamentals of Business
Subject or unit name 8: ACCT2000 (v.2) Business Processes and Internal Controls
subject or unit description 1: This unit covers the formation negotiation and operation of contracts, the role and structure of the contents of a business contract including boilerplate and common clauses, risk management and termination clauses, the type and scope of contract remedies and dispute resolution.
subject or unit description 2: This unit provides some powerful tools for understanding how economies work. It introduces the concepts and methods of experimental and behavioural economics; models of economic growth, business cycles, and financial crises; and tools to understand and evaluate monetary, fiscal and other economic policies.
subject or unit description 3: Overview of Information Systems Development Lifecycles (SDLCs), activities, tools, techniques and methodologies. Overview of business problem analysis. Introduction to systems analysis & design information system requirements elicitation and specification. Introduction to system analysis and design. Introduction to user interface design principles and practices for user interface design.
subject or unit description 4: This unit provides students with an introduction to Decision Support Systems and Business Intelligence. Students will examine entry, manipulation and presentation of data using contemporary software as well as Modelling (including financial, statistical, forecasting and simulation). Students will also explore data concepts and skills including queries, reports, analysis, import and export of data as well as ethics and privacy of data.
subject or unit description 5: The unit aims to provide students with a solid foundation of fundamental principles of company law. Topics include: the context of company law, the role and functions of the Australian Securities and Investments Commission, types of business structures, incorporation and registration, the doctrine of legal personality, corporate fund raising and share capital, legal rules relating to shares and dividends, the internal management of companies, powers and duties of various stakeholders, rights and remedies of members, company insolvency and deregistration.
subject or unit description 6: Foundation unit around management accounting techniques integrated with statistical methods applied to; costing models, profit planning and decision making techniques.
subject or unit description 7: The unit aims to provide students with knowledge of accounting transactions. It applies the conceptual framework and the objectives of the financial statement. It focuses on understanding, defining and recognising various elements of financial statements and the use of a computerised accounting software. In addition, the unit teaches the application of selected international financial reporting standards and underlying accounting theories.
subject or unit description 8: Exploration of typical accounting information systems application such as sales, billing, inventory and general ledger. How these subsystems interface with one another, and the principle inputs, processes, files, outputs and controls associated with them. Major themes throughout the course include: objectives and procedures of internal control, typical business documents and reports, and system documentation - use of data flow diagrams, flowcharts and other documentation techniques.
subject or unit description 9: Organisational issues in the implementation of information systems including success factors, business process redesign, user resistance, Information system evaluation, benefits realisation, occupational heath and safety and contractual requirements. Project management requirements including system and acceptance testing, software and hardware installation, data uptake or conversion, system introduction strategies, user training and user support.
subject or unit description 10: This unit aims to improve students' knowledge of accounting standards, and examine a number of important accounting issues relating to companies, particularly accounting for provision; contingent liabilities and assets; accounting policies; impairment of assets, property plant and equipment; tax effect accounting; shares and reserves; and statement of cash flows.

Description: Computer scientists, software engineers, programmers and other computing professionals are experts on how technology works and how computing can address even the most complicated and intricate problems.
Career outcomes: Computer programmer, IT professional, Computer security professional, Software engineer/developer
Remarks: Curtin requires all applicants to demonstrate proficiency in English. Specific English requirements for this course are outlined in the IELTS table below.
Subject or unit name 5: NPSC1002 (v.1) Science, Technology and Global Problems
subject or unit description 1: This unit builds on students’ knowledge of calculus and linear algebra, further extending to a range of techniques and used in solving problems arising from science, engineering and business related fields. Students will extend their differentiation skills to consider a broader range of functions, and will apply their differentiation techniques to approximation and finding Taylor series. This unit will cover a range of integration techniques, and students will apply these to determine several physical properties and applications. Students will extend their previous work on vectors, lines and planes into general n-dimension space and the study of vector spaces. This unit also covers matrices and their use for solving systems of linear equations through a study of a number of different types of solution methods, as well as the calculation and application of eigenvalues and eigenvectors. This unit is designed for those students who have passed Mathematics Specialist ATAR or equivalent, with a mark of 70% or greater.
subject or unit description 2: This unit will consider problems arising from science, engineering and business related fields. Students will learn the necessary skills to model and solve such problems through the introduction of mathematical techniques of linear algebra as well as complex analysis. Students will be introduced to idea of a complex number together with their applications and use in solutions to polynomial equations. This unit will cover vectors, lines and planes and their extension into n-dimension space. This unit also covers matrices and their use for solving systems of linear equations through a study of a number of different types of solution methods. Eigenvalues and eigenvectors will be considered. This unit is designed for those students who have passed WACE Mathematical Applications or Mathematical Methods or equivalent.
subject or unit description 3: An introduction to software engineering practices, including project management, requirements analysis and specification, testing, inspection, version control, and assessing and improving design quality. Discusses agile and traditional approaches to development.
subject or unit description 4: Students will be introduced to the Linux operating system and programming environment. They will then learn how to design software in pseudocode, and implement their designs in the Java programming language. Topics covered include: compiling and executing a Java program; primitive and reference data types; numeric expressions; the principles behind programming control structures and their implementation in Java; the design and implementation of sub-modules; file input and output; and searching and sorting. The unit also includes applications to real-world problems and number systems.
subject or unit description 5: Science and Technology are critical tools for addressing global problems. This unit investigates the nature of knowledge, science, data and problems with a global focus. Working in inter-disciplinary teams, students focus on the development of practical and theoretical solutions to real global problems using current and emerging scientific fields. In doing so they develop important skills in defining problems, scientific inquiry, building and working effectively in teams.
subject or unit description 6: This unit continues to build on students’ knowledge of calculus and vectors, further extending to a range of advanced techniques used in solving problems arising from science, engineering and business related fields. Students will apply their differentiation and integration techniques while learning to solve several types of first and second order differential equations, applying these in a variety of contexts. Students will be introduced to multivariable calculus, and will use vector calculus techniques to analyse the behaviour of functions of multiple variables. This unit will build on students’ capabilities in limits and sequences, considering a range of techniques including for multivariable limits, and will also cover several techniques for testing the convergence of a series.
subject or unit description 7: This unit builds on students’ knowledge of calculus, further extending to a range of techniques used in solving problems arising from science, engineering and business related fields. Students will extend their differentiation skills to implicit, logarithmic and partial differentiation, and will apply their differentiation techniques to optimisation problems and the approximation of functions. This unit will cover a range of integration techniques, and students will apply these to find volume, length and surface area. Students will also learn to solve a variety of first and second order differential equations, and be introduced to several techniques for testing the convergence of a series. This unit is designed for those students who have passed Mathematics Methods ATAR or equivalent.
subject or unit description 8: This unit introduces students to the C programming language and the related concepts and tools used to design, implement, test and debug C programs. Topics covered include: C Fundamentals. Functions and program structure. Designing programs with derived types. Pointers. Abstract data types. Strings, streams and input/output (I/O). Dynamic memory allocation and C programming utilitiers for program construction and diagnosis.
subject or unit description 9: Introduction to database systems, relational model and basic structured query language (SQL), entity relationship (ER) model and ER to relational mapping. Advanced SQL, SQL programming, triggers, relational algebra, normalisation, integrating databases into external programs, transactions and concurrency control. Database installation and maintenance.
subject or unit description 10: Introduction to fundamental data structures, algorithms and techniques in computing. Basic structures include stacks, queues and linked lists. Advanced structures explored are trees, hash tables and heaps. Algorithms discussed include sorting and recursion. Complexity analysis of these areas is also examined.

Description: Businesses rely on information systems to obtain, process and output information. They need professionals who can analyse and identify any issues, and propose the best systems solution.

Remarks: Curtin requires all applicants to demonstrate proficiency in English. Specific English requirements for this course are outlined in the IELTS table below.
Subject or unit name 1: ISYS2002 (v.1) Introductory Systems Analysis and Design
subject or unit description 1: Overview of Information Systems Development Lifecycles (SDLCs), activities, tools, techniques and methodologies. Overview of business problem analysis. Introduction to systems analysis & design information system requirements elicitation and specification. Introduction to system analysis and design. Introduction to user interface design principles and practices for user interface design.
subject or unit description 2: Organisational issues in the implementation of information systems including success factors, business process redesign, user resistance, Information system evaluation, benefits realisation, occupational heath and safety and contractual requirements. Project management requirements including system and acceptance testing, software and hardware installation, data uptake or conversion, system introduction strategies, user training and user support.
subject or unit description 3: This unit provides students with an introduction to Decision Support Systems and Business Intelligence. Students will examine entry, manipulation and presentation of data using contemporary software as well as Modelling (including financial, statistical, forecasting and simulation). Students will also explore data concepts and skills including queries, reports, analysis, import and export of data as well as ethics and privacy of data.
subject or unit description 4: Hardware, software, operating systems, networking, security, LAN protocols, network services and Unix scripting. Intermediate Business Technology.
subject or unit description 5: Considerations of physical security; control of access; security considerations in the design, testing, implementation of computer systems including the role of standards; administrative controls and their impact on reducing risk; controls in networks; recognition and measurement of potential loss; information systems audit concepts and techniques; scenarios and case studies.
subject or unit description 6: Principles of relational database modelling and design, including creation of a rational model from a conceptual (entity relationship) model, normalisation, integrity of data and databases, design and definition of database structures (tables, fields, indexes, sets and views), and use of structured query language (SQL) as a database interface language.
subject or unit description 7: Project Management of information management projects to ensure successful delivery on time and cost with quality. Includes scope, time and cost management; quality management; risk management; human resource management; communication management; procurement management. Use of a contemporary project management software package.
subject or unit description 8: Selection of software based on business information requirements, requests for proposal (RFP) and quotation (RFQ), system source investigation, evaluation of proposals and quotation, financial evaluation of information technology projects, vendor selection, and financing and contracting for hardware and software.
subject or unit description 9: Information systems management post implementation; information systems (IS) / information technology (IT) Governance; user support structures and processes including help desk management and software; information technology personnel management; information technology asset management; outsourcing; service level agreements; information security; privacy; risk management and disaster planning.
subject or unit description 10: This unit covers Network Operating Systems (NOS), network administration, configuration, network file system, security, troubleshooting, installation, LANs, WANs and network design.

Faculty: School of Electrical Engineering, Computing and Mathematical Sciences (EECMS)
Description: This course provides a coverage of aspects modern computing and computer networks. It covers fundamental programming and security knowledge as well as specializing in network programming and other aspects of distributed computing. The course teaching Python as a tool for learning programming Linux skills are taught throughout the course and emphasis is placed on learning the basics before moving onto advanced topics. Graduates from the course will have sound knowledge of computer systems and processes involved in software development and maintenance. The aim of this major is to prepare the students for the areas of ICT stated to be most in demand and for positions that are most difficult to fill. On completion of the three year degree, students who have performed well will be eligible to complete an extra year of study to obtain an honours qualification, BH-SCNCE Bachelor of Science (Honours). The research focus of an Honours degree provides a pathway for career advancement at a higher level than the base degree. Students who perform well in the this course can apply for transfer to the Bachelor of Computing course, although acceptance is not automatic.

subject or unit description 1: This unit will cover the core information security principles of confidentiality, integrity and availability. These core principles will be applied to the concepts of information risk management, and the analysis and handling of compromised systems. The ethics around computer crime, privacy, and intellectual property are covered in detail. Finally, the unit will cover the criteria and controls for information classification.
subject or unit description 2: This unit aims at equipping students with the ability to write simple programs as part of managing large volumes of data. Topics include data representation in a computer, algorithm design, submodules, Boolean expressions, selection and repetition control structures, basic Object Oriented programming design and File I/O. These will be discussed in the context of implementation in the Python programming language.
subject or unit description 3: Students will be introduced to Indigenous science, history, culture, knowledge and practices, and the value of integrating different knowledge systems to address global challenges. This unit focuses on developing the capacity of students to research, evaluate and communicate scientific and cultural information and arguments using written, visual and oral presentation techniques, while demonstrating inter-cultural awareness, scientific standards and academic integrity. In tandem, related ethical issues within STEM are explored, and particularly, the historic use of scientific ideas to justify social and political actions. The nature of science and scientific behaviours, the role and relevance of science and other knowledge systems in society, and methods of scientific inquiry are introduced to foster students' professional identities as scientists in Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) fields in the 21st century.
subject or unit description 4: An introduction to software engineering practices, including project management, requirements analysis and specification, testing, inspection, version control, and assessing and improving design quality. Discusses agile and traditional approaches to development.
subject or unit description 5:

Computer systems and network architectures.

Advanced structures explored are trees, hash tables and heaps. Algorithms discussed include sorting and recursion. Complexity analysis of these areas is also examined.

Students will learn the necessary skills to model and solve such problems through the introduction of mathematical techniques of linear algebra as well as complex analysis. Students will be introduced to idea of a complex number together with their applications and use in solutions to polynomial equations. This unit will cover vectors, lines and planes and their extension into n-dimension space. This unit also covers matrices and their use for solving systems of linear equations through a study of a number of different types of solution methods. Eigenvalues and eigenvectors will be considered. This unit is designed for those students who have passed WACE Mathematical Applications or Mathematical Methods or equivalent.
subject or unit description 8: This unit introduces students to the C programming language and the related concepts and tools used to design, implement, test and debug C programs. Topics covered include: C Fundamentals. Functions and program structure. Designing programs with derived types. Pointers. Abstract data types. Strings, streams and input/output (I/O). Dynamic memory allocation and C programming utilitiers for program construction and diagnosis.
subject or unit description 9:
Network management, standard mail protocol (SNMP) and International Standards Organisation (ISO) standards.
Introduction to data and communication networks.  Network architectures.  Protocol hierarchies.  Open Systems Interconnect (OSI) reference model. Network Management and Standard Mail Protocols (SNMP).
subject or unit description 10: Understanding of the design and management issues associated withthe operation and control of TCP/IP networks. The aim of this unit is to provide in-depth treatment on effective usage of active and passive monitoring/management tools and techniques, such as Network Mapping, NetworkMonitoring, Server Monitoring, the Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP), application-layer logging and the Lightweight Directory Access Protocol (LDAP). The Unit will also cover such issues as fault tolerance, disaster recovery, network security and HTTP issues.

Description: This double degree program provides graduates with a background in computer science and its application in computer systems and electrical, electronic and communication engineering. The combination of the two degrees provides graduates with versatility, which opens up a wide range of employment opportunities. On completion of the program, students are awarded both the Electrical and Electronic Engineering Honours and Computer Science Double Degree Major (BEng Hons/BSc).
Career outcomes: NULL
Remarks: Curtin requires all applicants to demonstrate proficiency in English. Specific English requirements for this course are outlined in the IELTS table below.
Subject or unit name 8: ELEN2001 (v.1) Electromagnetic and Electromechanical Energy Conversion
subject or unit description 1: Review of Direct Current (DC) resistive circuits and circuit theorems.  Nodal Voltage and Mesh Current methods of analysis.  Introduction to Alternate Current (AC) circuits and coupling circuits (mutual inductance and transformers).  Balanced and unbalanced 3-phase circuits and power calculations.  Frequency responses of Resistive-Inductive-Capacitive (R-L-C) circuits.  Transient circuit analysis, First and second orders.  Use of Laplace Transform in Circuit Analysis.  Operational amplifiers and Active filter circuits.
subject or unit description 2: An introduction to software engineering practices, including project management, requirements analysis and specification, testing, inspection, version control, and assessing and improving design quality. Discusses agile and traditional approaches to development.
subject or unit description 3: Sequences and series leading to Taylor’s series; Multidimensional analysis 2-D to n-D functions. Curve, plane and volume parameterisation. Complex functions. Graphing functions;  2-D, 3-D, n-D calculus. Line integrals. Surface integrals. Volume integrals. Iterated integrals; Probability theory. Sample space, events and the definition of probability. Joint and conditional probabilities, Bayes’ theorem, independent events and Bernoulli trials. Discrete and continues random variables, cumulative distribution functions, probability mass functions, probability density functions. Expectations, variances, functions of random variables. Engineering applications and probability theory.
subject or unit description 4: This unit introduces students to the C programming language and the related concepts and tools used to design, implement, test and debug C programs. Topics covered include: C Fundamentals. Functions and program structure. Designing programs with derived types. Pointers. Abstract data types. Strings, streams and input/output (I/O). Dynamic memory allocation and C programming utilitiers for program construction and diagnosis.
subject or unit description 5: Introduction to fundamental data structures, algorithms and techniques in computing. Basic structures include stacks, queues and linked lists. Advanced structures explored are trees, hash tables and heaps. Algorithms discussed include sorting and recursion. Complexity analysis of these areas is also examined.
subject or unit description 6: Topics to be addressed in this unit will include semiconductor doping, PN junction, diodes and circuits, physics of bipolar junction transistor, introduction on field effect transistor, elementary transistor amplification circuits, transistor biasing, device modelling, analysis and design of linear (small signal) single-stage amplifiers.
subject or unit description 7: The course will cover continuous-time and discrete-time signals, specifically their mathematical representations, properties and classifications, such as power and energy signals.  Special attention is devoted to Linear time-invariant systems, where concepts such as impulse response, convolution are developed. The course also cover the Fourier series representation of periodic signals, which leads to continuous-time Fourier transform (and discrete-time Fourier transform), Laplace transform and Sampling theorem. Students will be introduced to Matlab.
subject or unit description 8: Review of 3 Phase Circuits & Singly and Doubly Excited Systems. Review of magnetic circuit theory and flux linkages.   Three Phase Induction Motors.Transformers. Direct Current (DC) Motors.Single Phase Induction Motors. Fractional Horsepower motors.
subject or unit description 9: Artificial Intelligence, its main problems and approaches. Familiarity with symbolic representations, search methods, first-order logics and their applications in reasoning and learning tasks. Familiarity with numerical techniques in AI such as probabilistic networks and their applications. Search; Logic reasoning; Natural language Understanding; Machine Learning; Uncertainty.
subject or unit description 10: This unit focuses on digital design and computer architecture. It provides grounding on the foundations of digital logic design from the perspective of a Microprocessor without Interlocked Pipeline Storage (MIPS) processor architecture. Basic techniques on Boolean algebra and minimisation are covered to design combinational circuits and sequential systems which are building blocks to a MIPS. Using Electronic Design Automation (EDA) tools and Very High Speed Integrated Circuit Hardware Description Language (VHDL) and examining assembly programs, students will be able to gain further understanding in the complex world of computer architecture design.

Faculty: School of Electrical Engineering, Computing and Mathematical Sciences (EECMS)
Description: This course provides coverage of aspects of modern computing. It covers fundamental programming and theoretical knowledge followed by an opportunity to specialise in Cyber Security  The courses offers coverage of the key concepts and challenges in data and resource protection and computer software security. There are a focus on both the high level (e.g. cryptography theory and data access policy development and security program management) and low level practical (e.g. computer forensics, network intrusion detection and incident handling) aspects of computer security. The addition of programming techniques differentiates this course from more policy-based options. The aim of this course is to prepare the students for the areas of ICT stated to be most in-demand and for positions that are most difficult to fill.

Career outcomes: Computer programmer, IT professional, Computer security professional, Software engineer/developer
Remarks: Curtin requires all applicants to demonstrate proficiency in English. Specific English requirements for this course are outlined in the IELTS table below.

Faculty: School of Electrical Engineering, Computing and Mathematical Sciences (EECMS)
Description: This major sits within the Bachelor of Computing. To apply for this major, you will apply for the Bachelor of Computing.
Career outcomes: NULL
Remarks: At Curtin, we understand that everyone’s study journey has been different.
Subject or unit name 2: COMP3001 (v.1) Design and Analysis of Algorithms
Subject or unit name 7: COMP3002 (v.1) Theoretical Foundations of Computer Science
subject or unit description 1: This unit introduces intelligent agents and the artificial intelligence problems and approaches relating to them. Learners will become familiar with the modelling of autonomous agents, methods for programming agent behaviour as well as the basics of planning. This involves introducing a range of algorithms and logical processes which underlie agent behaviour. This unit introduces the need for machine learning in certain types of agents and introduces the logic involved but does not discuss details of machine learning techniques.
subject or unit description 2: Algorithms are an essential part of any efficient solutions for  computer  applications that evolve with the development in computing technologies. Therefore it is imperative for any computing student to have  sufficient knowledge of standard algorithm design techniques and analysis. In this unit the students will learn these standard  techniques: divide and conquer, greedy, and dynamic programming. The  unit shows how the techniques, among others, are used in sorting  algorithms, graph algorithms, data compression, 0/1 knapsack, string  searching, matrix-chain multiplication, longest common subsequence,  and parallel and distributed algorithms. The students will also learn  how to use the growth of functions concept to analyse algorithm resource requirement.
subject or unit description 3: This unit equips students to develop and communicate complex object oriented (OO) design structures for a given set of software requirements. The unit focuses on selected polymorphic design patterns to impart a set of techniques for creating highly cohesive and loosely-coupled designs. It takes students from high-level Unified Modelling Language (UML) design notations to their practical implementation in OO programming languages. Students also learn about the Model View Controller (MVC) architecture to help promote separation of concerns, containers and generics to promote design reuse, and factories and dependency injection to help address design testability.
subject or unit description 4: The operating systems are a critical part of any computer systems, and  therefore it is important for all computing students to have  sufficient knowledge of operating systems that evolve with the  development of computer technologies. In this unit students will learn  the following main OS components: process, thread, and their  communication and synchronizations; CPU scheduling algorithms;  deadlock detection, prevention, and avoidance; memory management,  including memory allocation, memory paging and segmentation, and  virtual memory; file system interface, implementation, and access methods; disk structure, scheduling, management and reliability; I/O management; and protection and security concepts and implementations.
subject or unit description 5:
This unit is an introduction to computer communications and networks technology. It covers fundamental knowledge on the design and implementation of networks and network protocols. The contents of the unit  are listed as below:
Introduction to Computer Communications.
Physical Layer.
Data Link Layer I.
Data Link Layer II.
Network Layer I.
Network Layer II.
Transport Layer I.
Transport Layer II.
Application Layer I.
Application Layer II.
Security.
subject or unit description 6: Introduction to database systems, relational model and basic structured query language (SQL), entity relationship (ER) model and ER to relational mapping. Advanced SQL, SQL programming, triggers, relational algebra, normalisation, integrating databases into external programs, transactions and concurrency control. Database installation and maintenance.
subject or unit description 7: Automata theory: deterministic and non-deterministic automata and conversions. Grammars: context free grammars, languages for grammars and Parse trees. Turing machines and abstractions of RAM. Decidability, reducibility P and PN classes. Time and spare complexity. NP completeness.
subject or unit description 8:
Software engineering projects are selected and undertaken in consultation with a member of the academic staff, usually working in a small group in conjunction with an industry partner or a designated client. Projects are related to the design, implementation and testing of software systems with associated literature reviews. Team-oriented software engineering processes are applied during all phases of the project. Management activities are undertaken and a range of software engineering tools are applied to resolve problems arising during the execution of the software development process. The main focus of this unit is problem identification and the development of a project proposal.

Students from each degree and major will be given tasks specific to that degree and major as part of their project work.
subject or unit description 9: An introduction to human computer interfaces, including the motivation and contexts for using these. The class teaches a process for user centred development as well as different measures for evaluation and models that inform human computer interface design. Social issues influencing human computer interface design and use are considered, as well as multi-cultural interaction and communication in order to accommodate human diversity. The different user interface standards and principles of graphical user interfaces are covered in addition to designing and programming GUIs both in native and web formats and widgets. Geometry management, event management and user interaction are introduced. Finally, user interface programming environments and future developments are discussed.
subject or unit description 10: Machine learning, its formulation, main problems and approaches. Familiarity with the formulation of machine learning from data. Familiarity with fundamental machine learning approaches including linear regression, linear classifiers, support vector machines, decision tree methods, Bayesian networks. Familiarity with the fundamentals of advanced machine learning techniques including feedforward neural networks, convolutional neural networks, residual neural networks and their training techniques.

Physical Layer.
